columns.text: In this exercise, we'll analyze an essential characteristic of stock called the price-to-earnings (PE) benchmark.

The price-to-earnings (PE) benchmark **is a valuation metric that compares a company's current share price to its earnings per share.** We can calculate the price-to-earnings (PE) benchmark by dividing the price by the earnings per share: $$\text{PE} = \dfrac{\text{Price}}{\text{Earning per share}} \tag{1}$$ Investors and analysts use PE benchmarks to measure a stock's relative value against other similar stocks. Investors can also use the PE benchmark to compare a stock's past performance. Generally, companies with a high PE benchmark grow their profits more than those with a low PE. On the other hand, a low PE is usually a feature of undervalued stocks or those that are performing exceptionally well compared to their historical patterns.

We are given the following information:

1. The earnings per share are $3.18.

2. The benchmark PE is 18.

We can use Eq.$(1)$ to find the appropriate stock price:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PE} &= \dfrac{\text{Price}}{\text{Earning per share}} \\[15pt]
\text{Price}&= \text{PE} \times \text{Earnings per share} \\[15pt]
\text{}&= 18 \times \$3.18 \\[15pt]
&= \$57.24
\end{aligned}$$

If price-to-earnings (PE) benchmark were 21, the stock price would be: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Price}&= \text{PE} \times \text{Earnings per share} \\[15pt] \text{}&= 21 \times \$3.18 \\[15pt] &= \$66.78 \end{aligned}$$

**Let's recap what we have done in this exercise!** First, we explained the fundamental concept of this exercise - the price-to-earnings (PE) benchmark. We have discussed its definition and where it's commonly used (and for what purpose). Finally, we used the price-to-earnings (PE) benchmark to find the appropriate stock price for the given earnings per share.
